newsitem.title: USA: Blue chips soar; market confident on interest rates.
newsitem.headline: Blue chips soar; market confident on interest rates.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks jumped Monday as investors grew more confident that the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates only modestly, if at all, later this month.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 73.98 points, or 1.31 percent, at 5,733.84, just below its record closing high of 5,778.00 set on May 22.
In the broader market, advancing issues beat declines 1,536 to 851 on moderate volume of 310 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said investors took a second look at Friday's August jobs report and attributed some of the data's strength to seasonal factors.
"There's some renewed investor confidence for the time being that inflation and interest rates are not a problem," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co.
On Friday, the Dow index surged 53 points after an increase of 250,000 in non-farm payrolls for August was not as strong as many had feared.
"A lot of the new employees were teachers and managerial types. The more you look at it, there's a seasonal swing," said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers.
"Portfolio managers drew a little courage from the figures and there's the expectation of no move by the Fed," Metz said.
He said Monday's buying was mostly concentrated in blue chips. "People did not have the courage to trade down."

The central bank's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, which meets on Sept. 24, last changed monetary policy in January, when it lowered the federal funds rate by one-quarter percentage point to its current target rate of 5.25 percent.
Opinions are mixed as to whether the central bank will decide this time to raise or leave interest rates unchanged, perhaps until after the Nov. 5 presidential election.

In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32 of a point, or $4.375 per $1,000 face value, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, dropped to 7.07 percent from Friday's close of 7.11 percent.
Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Cathy Minehan cited only limited signs of price pressures in the otherwise healthy economy.

"Throughout this period of strong employment and output performance, the core rate of inflation remained remarkably well-behaved," Minehan told the annual conference of the Association of Business Economists in Boston on Monday.

"Surges in oil and grain prices contributed to a small increase in overall consumer price inflation. But it appears that these industry-specific price disruptions may not feed into overall wages and prices," she said.
Analysts said the market will be closely watching this week's inflation barometers, especially the August Producer Prices Index, due Thursday, and the Consumer Price Index on Friday.
Gold mining stocks fell as inflation fears ebbed. Newmont Gold Co. lost 1-3/4 to 52-1/2 and Newmont Mining Corp. fell 1-1/8 to 51-3/4.

Stovall said oil stocks, which have been supported by U.S.-Iraq tensions, "have quieted down." Chevron Corp. rose 1/8 to 60-3/8, Texaco Inc. added 1/2 to 93-1/2 and Exxon Corp. inched up 1/4 to 84-1/4.

Among other blue-chips, United Technologies Corp. rose 3-1/2 to 115-3/4, International Business Machines Corp. gained 2-3/8 to 117-5/8, Caterpillar Inc. was up 1-3/4 to 73-1/2, DuPont Co. rose one to 84-5/8, and Union Carbide Corp. was up 1-7/8 to 45-1/8.

A spate of merger announcements galvanised some buying interest. Big B Inc. climbed 3-1/4 to 15-7/8 and was the most-active Nasdaq issue after a hostile $15 a share offer from Revco D.S. Inc., which slipped 1/8 to 25-1/2.

Britain's Danka Business Systems Plc agreed to buy Eastman Kodak Co.'s office imaging business and facilities management business for $684 million in cash. Danka surged 6-5/8 to 36-1/2 in U.S. trading and Kodak slipped 1/2 to 71-3/4.
Also, Phar-Mor Inc. and ShopKo Stores Inc. said they will merge, creating a new company -- Cabot Noble Inc. Phar-Mor lost 3/4 to 7-3/8 and ShopKo lost 1/8 to 16-1/8.
DAKA International slumped 5-3/8 to 10 and DII Group Inc. lost four to 19 after both warned of earnings shortfalls.

SGS-Thomson Microelectronics surged four to 43-7/8 in U.S. trading on news that it developed an integrated circuit that protects digital video systems from copyright pirates who copy film, music and other material.
The Nasdaq Composite index rose 9.32 points to 1,148.71.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks was up 8.09 to 663.77. The American Stock Exchange index was up 1.94 to 561.96.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 3.61 to 356.28. The average share was up 40 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 6,515,512 up 65.760 or 1.02 percent.
